Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Situation2: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Story: I sat on the high lifeguard chair, laptop balanced on my knees, fingers flying over the keyboard as I tried to finish the code sample my mentor had assigned. The deadline was in three days, but I knew he expected quality work, not something rushed. Every few minutes, I glanced up, scanning the pool, reminding myself that safety came first. That’s when I noticed a group of teenagers gathering near the deep end, laughing and edging closer to the “No Diving” signs. My heart thudded. I knew the rules—no exceptions. I was supposed to enforce them, no matter what. But if I stopped now, I’d lose my train of thought, and the code would take twice as long. My mentor’s words echoed in my mind: “Show me you can handle responsibility.” But wasn’t this also responsibility? I felt the pressure mounting, torn between the expectation to be a diligent mentee and the duty to be a vigilant lifeguard. My hands hovered over the keyboard, eyes darting between the screen and the pool, caught in the impossible tug-of-war between two roles that both demanded my full attention.
